anchor.surface_text: In pursuance thereof, the petitioner was taken into custody on March 19, 1974. The detention order  for short, the first order  which was served

anchor.surface_text: The detention order  for short, the first order  which was served on the detenu at the time of his arrest on March 19, 1974. states whereas, the said Shri

facts.text: 170 odd bags of material including 7 tins of sawdust, 15 bags of flour yellow and Gherwa, 70 bags of chilli seed, black flour leaves, one bag of gypsum khaddi power and a tin of animal dung were recovered from the godown and flour mill owned/controlled by Shri Bankatlal.

anchor.surface_text: states whereas, the said Shri Bankat Lal has been indulging in rampant adulteration of essential foodstuff and supply thereof for companysumption by the companymunity at large, operating a factory and firm under the name and style of Laxmi Narain Moondra situated in Makrana Mohalla, Jodhpur for such adulteration, so much so, that 170 odd bags of material which among other things, includes 7 tins of sawdust, 15 bags of companyour  yellow and Gherwa , 70 bags of chilli seed, black companyour leaves, which look like tea leaves, one bag of gypsum  khaddi  power and a tin of animal dung, used and intended for use in adulteration of foodstaffs, which are piosonous and injurious to public health were recovered from your godown and one floor mill owned and or companytrolled by the said Shri Bankatlal

facts.text: Recovery from the godown and flour mill includes foodstuff like Haldi, Mirchi, and Amchoor, which on chemical examination by the Public Analyst have been found to be adulterated.

anchor.surface_text: And, whereas recovery from the godown and flour mill mentioned in the preceding paragraph, also includes foodstuff like Haldi, Mirchi, and Amchoor, which on chemical examination by the Public Analyst have been found to be adulterated for which prosecution is companytemplated against the said Shri Bankatlal under the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954

facts.text: The second order containing further particulars of the grounds of detention was served on the petitioner on March 20, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: The second order companytaining further particulars of the grounds of detention was served on the petitioner on March 20, 1974. It reads x x x I . That on 11-3-1974 between 11 - 30 a.m.

facts.text: On 11-3-1974 between 11:30 a.m. and 2 p.m., Dr. Miss Raj Kumari, District Chief Medical and Health Officer Jodhpur and others raided the shop and godowns of Laxmi Narain Moondra at Killikhana, Makrana Mohalla, Jodhpur based on information from Shri Hiranand.

anchor.surface_text: It reads x x x I . That on 11-3-1974 between 11 - 30 a.m. and 2 p.m. Dr.  Miss  Raj Kumari, District Chief Medical and Health Officer Jodhpur together with . . . . . went to Sumer Market . . .where one Shri Hiranand son of Shri Lal Chand Sindhi, retailer gave credible information that you are owning a business firm named as Laxmi Narain Moondra a wholesale companycern at Killikhana, Makrana Mohalla, Jodhpur

facts.text: Raids and searches conducted between 11-3-1974 and 14-3-1974 confirmed information of adulteration.

anchor.surface_text: and you are doing wholesale business of adulteration of essential companymodities  foodstuffs  by adultering cheap unhygenic and injurious materials like companyours, saw-dust, gypsum, Gharu and sand with chilly-seeds, Haldi, Dhania, Amchur, tea-leaves and flour and manufacture adulterated foodstuffs for sale to the general public as pure varieties of such essential companymodities. When the party raided your above shop and four godowns situated in the same premises and searched there between 11-3-1974 and 14-3-1974, the information given by Shri Hiranand was companyfirmed.

facts.text: Petitioner and his son were found present in the shop during the raid on 11-3-1974.

anchor.surface_text: You, together with your son were found present in your shop and on the search of your premises the checking party found under your ownership and companytrol huge quantities of adulterated foodstuffs as well as the materials used by you for the purpose of adulterating essential companymodities.

facts.text: On 11-3-1974 in main shop: Eleven full bags and seven half-bags of adulterated chilli powder, weighing 80 Kg. to 20 Kg. each; one quintal bag of Haldi powder and two half bags; ten to twenty kg. bags of Amchur powder; one tin of Dhaniya mixed with refuse; two tins of Tumba oil.

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of the recovery memos of the articles seized show that you possessed the stock of following adulterated articles for manufacture, sale and storage of foodstuffs for sale under your companytrol. On 11-3-1974 in your main shop- Eleven full bags and seven half-bags of adulterated chilli powder, weighing 80 Kg. to 20 Kg. each. One quintal bag of Haldi powder and two half bags of the same. Ten to twenty kg. bags of Amchur powder. one tin of Dhaniya mixed with refuse. Two tins of Tumba oil.

facts.text: Samples of foodstuffs taken on 11-3-1974 by paying price in presence of motbirs.

anchor.surface_text: Samples of each of the above foodstuffs were taken on 11 3- 1974 by paying you. the price of each sample in the presence of Motbirs and forms IV and V were given to you sealing the articles in your, presence and companyy of the recovery memo, was also furnished to you.

facts.text: Samples examined by Public Analyst found highly adulterated: Chilli powder total ash 8.12% and ash insoluble 1.99%, contains silicious matter sand etc.; Haldi contains 46.24% heavily infested with insects; Amchur contains 20% extraneous matter.

anchor.surface_text: That the samples of foodstuffs sold by you to the Food inspector on 11-3-1974 were examined by the Public Analyst and found on examination highly adulterated companytaining Chilli powder-total ash 8.12 and ash insoluble in C. C. 1 .99 , companytains silicious matter sand etc. Haldi which companytains 46 .24 heavily infested with insects in such material. Amchur which companytains 20 extraneous matter.

facts.text: State Government approved the order of detention on March 23, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: Now some other material facts may be set out. The State Government approved the order of detention on March 23, 1974.

facts.text: Petitioner moved High Court of Rajasthan under Article 226 on or about April 6, 1974; dismissed on May 6, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: On or about the 6th April, 1974 the petitioner moved the High Court of Rajasthan under Article 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ of habeas companypus on the ground that his detention was illegal. The High Court dismissed the writ application on May 6, 1974.

facts.text: Reference to Advisory Board made on April 10, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: The re- ference to the Advisory Board was made on April 10,1974 in companypliance with s. 10.

facts.text: Detenu made representation dated 16/17th April 1974, despatched April 17, received by Government April 20, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: The detenu made a representation, dated 16/17th April 1974, which was despatched by the Superintendent, Central Jail, Jodhpur, on April 17, 1974, and was received by the Government on April 20, 1974.

facts.text: Advisory Board considered representation, heard detenu, reported sufficient cause for detention.

anchor.surface_text: The Government then forwarded that representation to the Advisory Board which companysidered it and heard the detenu in person and reported to the Government that there was sufficient cause for the detention.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention order on May 11, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government companyfirmed the detention order on May 11, 1974.

facts.text: District Magistrate stated in affidavit that he knew petitioner had been prosecuted and convicted earlier under PFA Act, but not mentioned in grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate had stated in his affidavit before the High Court that before passing the order of detention, he had companye to know that the petitioner had been prosecuted and companyvicted earlier under the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act.

facts.text: Petitioner argues donkey dung, saw-dust, gypsum etc. were not adulterants, kept for innocuous purposes; no evidence of mixing; samples sub-standard not adulterated.

anchor.surface_text: In elaboration of the first point, Mr. Sen submits that in the first place, the donkey dung, saw-dust, gypsum, I. C. I. Colours, companyoured plastic paper, dhaniya waste, etc. which were found in the premises were number adulterants. They were kept there for innocuous purposes. The donkey-dung was meant for being used as fuel the sawdust was there for preserving slabs of ice.

facts.text: Court finds presence of donkey-dung, sawdust, gypsum etc. in premises suspicious, relevant to detention; samples prima facie adulterated per PFA Act.

anchor.surface_text: Taking the first points first, the presence of donkey-dung, sawdust, gypsum, I. C. I. companyours, refuse, companyoured plastic, papers etc. stored in tins, bags or other receptacles, in premises where spices and other foodstuffs were also lying stored, some of which were found adulterated was by itself a suspicious circumstance.

facts.text: Chilli powder, Amchoor and Haldi-whole taken from premises were prima facie adulterated articles per Public Analyst reports and s.2(1) PFA Act.

anchor.surface_text: There companyld be numberdoubt that on the basis of the reports. of the public Analyst, the chilli powder, Amchoor and Haldi- whole taken from the premises of the petitioner were prima facie adulterated articles.

facts.text: Petitioner was previously convicted once under PFA Act based on confession.

anchor.surface_text: it has been admitted before us, as was done before the High Court, that the petitioner was only once companyvicted for an offence under the Prevention of Food Adulteration Art.

facts.text: Court holds food adulteration activity prejudicial to maintenance of supplies and services essential to community under s.3(1)(a)(iii) MISA.

anchor.surface_text: Is food adulteration activity an activity prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services to the companymunity? For reasons that follow, the answer to this question, in our opinion must be in the affirmative.
Petition Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India K. Sen, Badri Das Sharma and S. K. Bagga, for the Petitioner.

arguments.court_reasoning: Presence of materials suspicious; samples prima facie adulterated per Public Analyst and PFA s.2(1); relevant to detention.

arguments.claim: Donkey dung, saw-dust, gypsum etc. found in premises were not adulterants but kept for innocuous purposes like fuel or preserving ice

anchor.surface_text: In elaboration of the first point, Mr. Sen submits that in the first place, the donkey dung, saw-dust, gypsum, I. C. I. Colours, companyoured plastic paper, dhaniya waste, etc. which were found in the premises were number adulterants. They were kept there for innocuous purposes. The donkey-dung was meant for being used as fuel the sawdust was there for preserving slabs of ice.

arguments.court_reasoning: Suspicious circumstance in premises with adulterated foodstuffs; no license for such materials; doubtful explanations.

arguments.claim: No evidence that alleged adulterants were being used to adulterate spices or foodstuffs

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, there was numberevidence, whatever, that these articles were being used to adulterate the spices or other foodstuffs for sale.

anchor.surface_text: It is stressed that numbere of the foodstuffs taken from the premises was found adulterated or mixed with these alleged adulterants viz., donkey-dung, sawdust I. C. I. companyour etc. The only extraneous matter in the sample of chilli powder detected by the Public Analyst-proceeds the argument-was 1 .99 , sand.

arguments.court_reasoning: Prima facie adulterated per PFA s.2(1)(b),(c),(f) based on ash, insects, extraneous matter.

arguments.claim: No nexus between alleged adulterants and sub-standard foodstuffs

anchor.surface_text: It is urged that there was numbernexus between the alleged adulterants and the foodstuffs the samples of which were found sub-standard.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e activities of the person sought to be detained, in the proximate past and present, is such as to enable it to make a reasonable pro- gnosis of the p

arguments.court_reasoning: Bulk extraneous matter relevant given systematic adulteration info.

arguments.claim: Detaining authority erred by considering irrelevant adulterants, vitiating order

anchor.surface_text: The detaining authority had therefore in taking into account these alleged adulterant, erred and based the order of detention on an irrelevant companysideration. Since it cannot be predicated, argues the Counsel, to what extent the authority was influenced by this irrelevant matter, the order stands vitiated.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ercircumstances pre-indicative of the offenders propensity to indulge in adulteration in the future, it may number be proper to exercise the power of

arguments.court_reasoning: Not irrelevant; suspicious and strengthening evidence of adulteration.

arguments.claim: Grounds communicated to detenu not germane, lacking direct nexus to maintenance of supplies/services essential to community

anchor.surface_text: 2  The grounds companymunicated to the detenu are number germane having a direct nexus with the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity

arguments.court_reasoning: Food adulteration prejudicial to supplies/services; spices essential commodities; supplies mean wholesome form, not adulterated.

arguments.claim: District Magistrate knew of previous prosecution/conviction under PFA but not mentioned in grounds, depriving opportunity to explain, rendering detention illegal

anchor.surface_text: 3  The District Magistrate had stated in his affidavit before the High Court that before passing the order of detention, he had companye to know that the petitioner had been prosecuted and companyvicted earlier under the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts within detenu's knowledge; not essential to grounds substance; opportunity before Advisory Board.

arguments.claim: Public Analyst reports indicate possibility of adulterants like dung, sawdust, gypsum in chilli powder and Amchoor samples

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Singhvi, learned Counsel for the State, submits that the reports of the Public Analyst, far from excluding, strongly indicated the possibility of the samples of, chilli powder and Amchoor companytaining a substantial percentage, of animal dung, sawdust, gypsum and waste matter.

arguments.court_reasoning: Analyst did not exclude; gypsum possible in insoluble ash/extraneous matter.

arguments.claim: Seizure of adulterants with adulterated foodstuffs relevant and germane to object of detention (maintenance of supplies/services)

anchor.surface_text: On these premises, it is maintained, the seizure of the aforesaid adulterants along with the adulterated foodstuffs for sale, was highly relevant and germane to the object of the detention viz., maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ercircumstances pre-indicative of the offenders propensity to indulge in adulteration in the future, it may number be proper to exercise the power of

arguments.claim: Chilli powder, Amchoor, Haldi-whole samples prima facie adulterated per Public Analyst and PFA s.2(1)

anchor.surface_text: There companyld be numberdoubt that on the basis of the reports. of the public Analyst, the chilli powder, Amchoor and Haldi- whole taken from the premises of the petitioner were prima facie adulterated articles.

arguments.claim: Presence of donkey-dung, sawdust etc. in premises with adulterated foodstuffs is suspicious and relevant

anchor.surface_text: Taking the first points first, the presence of donkey-dung, sawdust, gypsum, I. C. I. companyours, refuse, companyoured plastic, papers etc. stored in tins, bags or other receptacles, in premises where spices and other foodstuffs were also lying stored, some of which were found adulterated was by itself a suspicious circumstance.

arguments.claim: Food adulteration is activity prejudicial to maintenance of supplies/services essential to community under MISA s.3(1)(a)(iii)

anchor.surface_text: This takes us to the second point. It raises the question Is food adulteration activity an activity prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services to the companymunity? For reasons that follow, the answer

arguments.claim: Supplies under s.3(1)(a)(iii) means supply of essential commodities/foodstuffs in wholesome form, not adulterated substitutes

anchor.surface_text: Supplies in the companytext of s. 3 1   a   iii  means the supply of essential companymodities or foodstuffs in a wholesome form. It does number mean the supply of their adulterated substitute.

arguments.claim: Misri Lal v. State wrongly holds food adulteration not prejudicial to supplies
Adulteration = acting prejudicially to supply of essential commodity (following Hari Ram v. State)

anchor.surface_text: In Our opinion, therefore, adulterating an essential companymodity is acting prejudicially to the maintenance of its supply and the provisions of sec. 3 1   a  are clearly attracted.

arguments.claim: Preventive detention power different from punitive; can coexist with prosecution

anchor.surface_text: The power of preventive detention is qualitatively different from punitive detention. The power of preventive detention is a precautionary power exercised in reasonable anticipation.

arguments.claim: Subjective satisfaction of DM reasonable based on materials
arguments.court_reasoning: Materials on past/present activities enable prognosis of future prejudicial acts.

arguments.claim: Non-communication of previous conviction details does not violate Art.22(5)/s.8(1) MISA

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact, therefore, that all the details of his previous prosecutions and their results or his companyviction were number companyveyed to the detenu did number companytravene Art. 22  5  of the Constitution and s. 8 1  of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Within detenu's knowledge; grounds substance intact; opportunity to explain available.

arguments.claim: Only habitual/large-scale adulteration justifies preventive detention; petty cases do not

anchor.surface_text: But every petty, or ordinary act of adulteration of foodstuffs will number justify preventive action under the Act. It is only adulteration carried on habitually or in a big way that throws out of gear the even tempo of life.

arguments.claim: Reasonable prognosis test: past/present activities predict future behavior

holdings.text: The grounds of detention are existent and relevant as the presence of suspicious materials and prima facie adulterated foodstuffs provides a rational basis for the detention order.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Suspicious presence of potential adulterants in bulk in premises with confirmed adulterated samples per Public Analyst reports; not irrelevant; nexus to prejudicial activity.

holdings.text: Chilli powder, Amchoor, and Haldi-whole samples are prima facie adulterated articles under Section 2(1) of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Public Analyst reports show excess ash, insoluble matter, insects, extraneous matter falling under PFA s.2(1)(b),(c),(f); gypsum/sawdust not ruled out.

holdings.text: Food adulteration activity is prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community under s.3(1)(a)(iii) of MISA.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Essential commodities like spices must be supplied in wholesome form, not adulterated; distinguishes Misri Lal (too narrow), follows Hari Ram; extends to services; organized/large-scale justifies detention.

holdings.text: Supplies under s.3(1)(a)(iii) MISA means supply of essential commodities/foodstuffs in wholesome form, not their adulterated substitutes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation to protect community health and even flow of essentials; adulteration disrupts supply integrity.

holdings.text: Non-communication of details of previous conviction under PFA Act does not contravene Article 22(5) or s.8(1) MISA.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts within detenu's knowledge; not part of grounds' substance; opportunity to explain before Advisory Board; prior prosecution indicated in orders.

holdings.text: District Magistrate's subjective satisfaction is reasonable and valid based on materials of past and present activities.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Materials enable prognosis of future prejudicial acts; bulk adulteration, systematic nature justify apprehension of continuation.

holdings.text: Preventive detention is qualitatively different from punitive detention and can coexist with prosecution under PFA.

anchor.surface_text: The power of preventive detention is qualitatively different from punitive detention. The power of preventive detention is a precautionary power exercised in reasonable anticipation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precautionary based on future probability, not past punishment; quotes Haradhan Saha; prosecution no bar.

holdings.text: Petty or ordinary adulteration does not justify preventive detention under MISA; only habitual/large-scale does.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proportionality required; extraordinary power for significant threats only; caution against abuse.

holdings.text: Reasonable prognosis test for preventive detention: assess past/present activities to predict future prejudicial behavior, considering nature, magnitude, impact.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Guidance for authorities in adulteration cases; factors like scale, impact relevant.

precedents.citation: Misri Lal v. The State  1 ... A.I.R. 1951 Pat. 134 F.B.

anchor.surface_text: In Misri Lal v. The State  1 , a Full Bench of the Patna High Court, ,speaking through Imam J.  as he then was  took a different view in these terms I do number think that the words maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity companyld reasonably carry the meaning that any one who adulterated foodstuffs would be acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies or the companytinuity of supplies. It is true that adulterated foodstuff A.I.R. 1951 Pat. 134 F.B.

precedents.cited_proposition: adulteration of foodstuffs would not be acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies or the continuity of supplies
precedents.cited_holding: I do number think that the words maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity companyld reasonably carry the meaning that any one who adulterated foodstuffs would be acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies or the companytinuity of supplies

anchor.surface_text: The view in Misri Lals case  supra  was dissented from by a Bench of the Rajasthan High Court in Hari Ram v. State.  1  Commenting on the decision of Misri lals case, that Court said In our opinion the crucial words of the statute areacting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies.

precedents.cited_proposition: view that food adulteration is not prejudicial to maintenance of supplies

precedents.citation: Hari Ram v. State.  1 ... 1974 25 Raj. Law Weekly p. 26

anchor.surface_text: The view in Misri Lals case  supra  was dissented from by a Bench of the Rajasthan High Court in Hari Ram v. State.  1  Commenting on the decision of Misri lals case, that Court said In our opinion the crucial words of the statute areacting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies. The burden is number on maintenance as it merely imports companytinuity.

precedents.cited_proposition: food adulteration activity is prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies of essential commodities as it supplies counterfeit instead of genuine
precedents.cited_holding: adulterating an essential companymodity is acting prejudicially to the maintenance of its supply and the provisions of sec. 3 1   a  are clearly attracted

precedents.citation: Jagdish Prasad v. State of Bihar

anchor.surface_text: Recently in Jagdish Prasad v. State of Bihar, a decision to which one of us was a party- the connotation, scope and inter-relationship of the terms supplies and services9 in s. 3  1   1   1974  25 Raj. Law Weekly p. 26.  a   iii  of the Act came up for examination in the companytext of blackmarketing in foodgrains.

precedents.case_name: Jagdish Prasad v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: connotation, scope and inter-relationship of the terms supplies and services in s. 3(1)(a)(iii) of the Act
precedents.cited_holding: Light and power thus are companymodities so also food and water. Yet who will deny that light is a service or drinking water, for that matter? The touchstone of social companytrol is that it mast be a thing essential for the existence of the companymunity

State of West Bengal  1  the learned Chief Justice brought out this distinction thus The power of preventive detention is qualitatively different from punitive detention. The power of preventive detention is a precautionary power exercised in reasonable anticipation. ... Writ Petition No. 1999 of 1973 decided on 21-8-1974.

precedents.case_name: Haradhan Saha v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between preventive detention and punitive incarceration
precedents.cited_holding: The power of preventive detention is qualitatively different from punitive detention. The power of preventive detention is a precautionary power exercised in reasonable anticipation. It may or number relate to an offence.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the petition fails and is dismissed. Rule discharged.

outcome.relief_summary: The writ petition under Article 32 challenging the detention order is dismissed. Rule discharged. No relief granted to the petitioner.

Preventive detention concept c12 supports holding h3 applying it to food adulteration as prejudicial under MISA preventive detention provision
Upheld reasonable subjective satisfaction supports holding on prejudicial nature justifying detention.
The holding h3 that adulteration prejudices supplies is supported by the Reasonable Prognosis Test's assessment of past activities and impact.
Reasonable Prognosis Test prognoses future prejudicial behavior to supplies based on past activities, addressing nexus of grounds in i2.
Reasonable Prognosis Test considers nature, magnitude, and impact of adulteration to assess prejudice to supplies, addressing i4.
The holding that grounds provide a rational basis for detention is grounded in the doctrinal requirement that grounds must have rational nexus to the detention object.

The concept requiring rational nexus between grounds of detention and the detention object addresses the issue of whether grounds are non-existent, as lack of nexus implies non-existence or irrelevance.
